Lesson 4: Enforcing Contracts

Image by Romain Dancre under Unsplash

When the time comes to enforce contracts, all of your hard work outlining and communicating policies and documenting agreements will pay off. While contracts can be either verbal or written, it is best to have everything in writing when building and protecting your business.

Still need convincing to get everything in writing?

Consider this scenario:

A new family contacts you about enrolling their child in your center. You share the child care fees and the parent agrees to pay $250 a week for child care. At the end of the first week, the parent picks up their child and leaves without paying. When you contact them, they share that they thought it was $250 per month. If you had written child care policies and fee requirements and a contract everyone would have been clear about expectations. Moreover, written documentation helps protect your program from miscommunication and potential legal issues.

Another important question to ask yourself when it comes time to effectively enforce your contract and program policies is if you’ve clearly defined the rules and consistently follow them. If you frequently bend rules to fit different situations or you aren’t consistent in how you apply them, you will run into challenges when it is necessary to hold family or staff accountable.

Consider this example:

Your contract says parents are given one week of unpaid tuition “vacation” per year. Jamal attends 3 days a week and his mother informs you that they will be gone for the next two weeks and he will miss five days of care. She requests those five days that span almost two weeks as her vacation week. When you try to explain that each child is allocated just one vacation week, she points out that this is not clearly defined in the contract. What do you do now? It will be hard to enforce your contract if you haven’t clearly defined the policy and it can be interpreted in different ways. You will need to revise your contract in the future to define exactly what a “vacation” week is. Is a vacation week five free days for everyone or is it the number of days the child normally attends? Have it in writing and think through possible alternative interpretations so you don’t get into sticky situations like the one with Jamal’s mother.

Here are a few top tips for enforcing contracts:

  • Adequately describe all consequences for not complying with a policy or contract requirement in writing.
  • Avoid vague or incomplete language to avert communication problems with families and save time that you would otherwise have to spend constantly reassessing your policy and the actions necessary to enforce the policy in every situation that arises.
  • Consistently define and enforce the rules so parents and staff don’t feel you are being unfair or showing favoritism.
  • Eliminate rules you aren’t willing to enforce—inconsistent application can create conflict and potential legal issues.

Scenarios

Image by drobotdean under Freepik

Your plan of action may depend on your budget. Do you have the flexibility and cushion to be paid bimonthly instead of weekly? Do you have the bandwidth to manage an alternative payment schedule? If so, you may accept their proposal, but only if you develop a new contract that states the new schedule clearly, including late payment fees and process, and everyone agrees to it in writing.

Image by krakenimages.com under Freepik

Though you may be tempted to let the parent pay program fees later, you will be sending a message that the contract is flexible and that payments are not due when you say they are. Perhaps you probe for more information about when the parent will have the money for the registration fee so you have a complete understanding of the situation. Then, consider offering to hold the child’s enrollment spot until the program fee can be made, if you have the space to do so.

Image by cookie_studio under Freepik

If you never communicated a policy about Monday withdrawals, it’s unfair for you to enforce a late fee on families when funds are insufficient. Moreover, a lack of communication like this can harm your credibility and relationships with families. Imagine yourself in their shoes—how would you feel not knowing when money would be withdrawn from your account? Return to best practices—repair the relationship, add your policy in writing, communicate it clearly with parents, ideally in writing, and then enforce it consistently.

Image by freepik under Freepik

There is no perfect answer for unusual and difficult situations like this. Your response will depend on the situation and it may be in your best interest to gather information from them first, consult with colleagues or a resource center, and then return to the family with a compassionate and clear answer. As child care providers and administrators, we are an important piece of a social safety net for our families, and, at the very least, we must provide resources to help with extenuating circumstances.
